headline: Ocasio-Cortez: Green New Deal will transition US to 100 percent renewable energy
subHeadline: Is the Green New Deal filled with unrealistic proposals? Reaction and analysis on 'The Five.'

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino along with Lisa Boothe, Juan Williams, Brian Kilmeade, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is “The Five.” Major breaking news out of scandal plague Virginia, a defiant Ralph Northam just telling top aides he will not resign as governor despite mounting pressure to do so. This comes less than 24 hours after all of the state's Democratic congressman demanded he step aside.  And just moments ago, a second woman has come forward accusing Lieutenant Governor Justin Fairfax of sexual assault. Let's go to Trace Gallagher with the latest developments, putting it all of this together for us. Trace?

utterances.speaker: TRACE GALLAGHER, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Hi, Dana. Breaking right now, the second accuser is a woman name Meredith Watson who said this happened back in 2000 while they were both undergraduates at Duke University, and she claims at the time she share the account with several classmates who had apparently provided statements to authorities willing to back up that claim.  Now, her lawyer also says she shared the story with friends in a string of e-mails on Facebook. And if that's the case, they would clearly be a fairly significant social media footprint on this story. The woman calls this -- excuse me -- a premeditated aggressive assault. She's not offering details, but she says the details of her attack are similar to the one described by Vanessa Tyson. Remember that's the first accuser. And that case, Tyson say they were at a DNC convention back in Boston in 2004, and that Fairfax asked Tyson to go to his hotel room to get documents and then began kissing. They say the kissing was consensual, and then, she alleges that he put his hand behind her neck and forcefully pulled her head towards his crotch forcing her to perform oral sex on him. He says, in turn, that relationship, that whole thing was consensual.  The new accuser is now calling for him to resign as lieutenant governor and she now claims that she was upset to learn that he did this again to a second woman, being in 2004, four years after her allegations. Her attorney -- and I want to read you the statement -- just release and saying, and I'm quoting here, "at this time, Ms. Watson is reluctantly coming forward out of a strong sense of civic duty, and her belief that those seeking or serving in public office should be of the highest character. She has no interest in becoming a media personality or reliving the trauma that has greatly affected her life. Similarly, she is not seeking any financial damages."  And you mentioned at the top, this is all, kind of, important because Governor Ralph Northam still maintains that he will not step down over whether or not he was involved in a racist picture in his medical school yearbook back in 1984. Fairfax will be second in line. She wants him to step down as lieutenant governor. We're still waiting to hear from the Fairfax camp about this allegation. Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right, Trace, thank you so much. And so that's an important point that Trace just made. This news literally breaking while we were in the green room before we came out here. So, we haven't heard from the lieutenant governor yet. Juan, let me ask you about this that it was a week ago that we were here where we -- it was almost like to be sure that Governor Northam was going to resign. He has lost the support of all the Democrats within his own party. They're in Virginia, even in national level, the presidential candidate level. And we all believe that Justin Fairfax, lieutenant governor, could then step into his shoes. And now that looks possibly to be in doubt as well because Northam is not resigning and now you have the second accuser.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.sentences: Breaking news right here. You know, as you said as we were coming out the stuff about Justin Fairfax, the second accusation.   But I think the larger story here has to do with the governor refusing, as you say, to resign at this point, which seems incredible because it's not just a few small people who are thinking, oh, we're going to stick a finger in his eye and make fun of him, and it certainly not Republicans. I'm talking about Tim Kaine and Mark Warner. I'm talking about the entire congressional delegation -- Democratic delegation for the state of Virginia saying this man has to go. In addition to which the poll numbers have plummeted, his moral authority given that awful performance when he went before the press and said, oh, you know, it seems to be that I should apologize, and, oh, no, maybe it's not me in the picture. Oh, I'm going to have an investigation. It's just so duplicitous and not believable.  He has made this all about himself, Dana. And so, to that extent, if it's just him and his wife, the suggestion is that the wife has been encouraged to stay. Then, of course, he can stay for as long as he wants. He could possibly, I guess, be impeached or something like that. I don't know what the mechanism would be. But that's separate.   At this moment, he has made it all about himself. It's a very selfish act damaging not only to the Democratic Party in the state but to the state.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: What do you think about people that -- like Northam who go through something like this and then they refused to resign and they just hold on with no support?

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.sentences: Oh, I think a lot of this has to do with the changing nature of news. Like, you could almost -- you're confident now that you can probably --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Hold on?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- outlast anything because the news cycle is so quick. Hey, maybe something worse is going to come down. And he's actually right because worse things do come down. I mean, it's like we're watching like the worst game of war right now. You know, it's like first started with late term of abortion, then it was blackface, then sexual assault, then blackface and sexual assault.  We're talking about shutting down the government. We were -- we should shutdown the Virginia government maybe for about two weeks.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But I read on Twitter -- this is what gets me, so somebody verify this, but I think it's true because it was a blue checker who said this --

utterances.speaker: BRIAN KILMEADE, HOST
utterances.sentences: OK, I will. I'm on it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: OK, it's true. That -- this -- Northam's staff is having him read some books to rectify his wrongdoing, and one of them is like is Roots, Alex Haley's great book. And it's just -- so, imagine that, like -- if all of us could have that luxury to rectify wrongdoings by reading books, you would have to read, of course, the Joy of Cooking.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: To call back the case of --

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But I much prefer the Joy of Hate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, well, you know that's a great book and you know it's in paperback.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, I do. I know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Thank you for that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Indeed, indeed. Brian, what do you think?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, we had one block who is going to be about 15 minutes, we're going to talk about Virginia. That's how important to us talking about the news cycle, but now it's number one. I guess the feeling is why is Northam in a rush to start his exile? So where am I going to go? I can't go back to the medical field. It's going to be tough to line up that -- to fill up my waiting room. And I can't really go back to politics because I'm done.   So he knows -- I finish up the term, there's no grounds to the other way. Virginia law reads to impeach him so I can wait this out. He actually placed a call, I understand, to Fairfax to say, you know, hang in there, buddy. You know, it will get better. That was yesterday.  So, Tim Kaine and Mark Warner get together and they go, listen, let's -- you've got to leave. And he's like, I'm not going to leave. In fact, his buddy, Richard Stewart, who is a Republican, says Northam is not going to leave. He understands he has to stand up and face this, but has to explain a few things. For example, what is the name coon man mean? Who was that who you choose to put in your picture? And as the attorney general, believe it or not, Mark Herring, being that he went right to the Virginia Black Caucus and threw himself and said I'm guilty, I apologize, this is what I was thinking.  They were thinking we could get Northam to step up, and then let Herring step up because we'll forgive him because it was one thing dressing like a rapper as opposed to a medical page. He was in his 20's, and Herring is just 19.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: So on degrees, Herring was supposed to be the next governor then this happens to the lieutenant governor. Northam is not going to leave. So I think things stay as they are as Northam tries to navigate his legal situation.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And some Democrats like in the state, Lisa, they were told -- you know, just stay off TV because, as to Greg's point, like, let's just get through this and then something else will happen and we'll try to figure it out. But this seems like they're in a circular firing squad in Virginian.

utterances.speaker: LISA BOOTHE, HOST
utterances.sentences: Absolutely --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And you're a Virginian.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: I am a Virginian. But --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Do you have any skeletons?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: I don't.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Get them out now.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: I don't think so -- I'm just kidding. No, none of this. Nothing like this. No, no. But to Brian's point, the reason why Northam is not going to step down is he has nowhere to go. In Virginia you serve one term so he's not going to go to run for reelection. Democrat senators, Tim Kaine and Warner aren't going anywhere, so he has nowhere else to run, politically, when he's done serving his term. And then you have the two guys under you that are facing, you know, their own public relations disaster and own scandal.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: So, why would he step down considering those things? And the reason -- everyone keeps talking about this in the context of 2020 election, but you also have statewide legislative races that are up this November and those are important. And the reason why -- I'll tell you is you look -- even that bill that Virginia Democrat -- delegate trend (ph) introduced regarding third term abortion. Right now, that was stopped because Republicans have a very slight majority in the Virginia House of Delegates. If those dynamics change, that bill may get pass.  That's the same thing that happened in the state of New York when the Republicans lost the majority in the Virginia state -- sorry, New York Senate, and then Democrats are able to move forward with that third trimester abortion bill. So this is important stuff. Elections have consequences. And perhaps this ends up to bite Democrats this November.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Mention some breaking news in my ear, you know, that's where it comes in the breaking news in your ear. Governor Terry McAuliffe, former governor, has just now called for the immediate resignation of Lieutenant Governor Fairfax.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So I don't know exactly what Terry -- former Governor McAuliffe has in mind or why he felt this way, except that we now know that there's a second woman. I would say that from the Fairfax --

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: With the similar story, we should add.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK. I don't know the details of that story. But I would say that those initial person, the professor from out west, never filed criminal charges and she has no intent to file criminal charges. And I think we're hearing the same thing from the woman who is making the allegations about his behavior at Duke University.  The question then becomes -- so there's no criminal record, and you have, of course, varying accounts or memories. And again, we get into this this thing where, you know, forget Republican, Democrat, all that, it's just like, what -- how do you negotiate, navigate these very tricky waters? You don't want to be unfair to Fairfax in the way that we have wanted to be unfair on the Republican side to Kavanaugh.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: But do you think there's a difference in a sense where Justin Fairfax has, at least, said that they were at the same place at the same time and something went down between the two of them? Now, he says, obviously, it's consensual. Vanessa Tyson said that it was not. But it's very different than the Kavanaugh situations where -- the sense that he is admitting that something happen with this woman. They were at the same convention in 2004, and so there's at least something that happened. One is saying consensual, the other is not. Whereas with Kavanaugh, he said this never happened. I don't even remember what this woman is talking about.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But to Juan's point, which is very important, we've talked about this for a year, probably. Without due process there is no process. So you have -- it doesn't matter what side anybody is on, we're all on the same side of justice. And we have to, like -- this could really be true, it could -- might not be, we don't know.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: This happens in sports, sadly, all the time. They -- you know, you have a game on Sunday, and then accusation comes out on Thursday, and they say, hey guys, you've got to act because this just happened. How could you let them play? Well, let the process play out when there's no video and there's an accuser in a situation like this. Well, how can you let it play? Well, you don't know if he is guilty right now. How could you close circumstantial it seems obvious he is guilty. No, we have to wait. That's what the problem with sports all the time.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And that's the thing that happened with former Governor McAuliffe. So, the other thing he said is because of the second accuser, without the investigation, due process, and all that, immediate resignation, serious accusations, and that he can no longer effectively serve the people of Virginia.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think it's the power here of what you're hearing from former Governor McAuliffe is the pattern. If there's a pattern established, well, that could tip the scales.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: But then, again, I can read this, not like this guy and say I have something that would show a pattern.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Although, she's also saying -- as Trace -- Atkins --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You've got country music on your mind.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Different guy. Different guy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Trace Gallagher said --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Would that be great, though?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- lawyer say that she has emails or sort of Facebook messages. Again, this is just breaking just now, so we don't have all the details but we'll continue to follow it for you. So next, extortion, blackmail, and salacious photos, billionaire Jeff Bezos has battle with the National Enquirer, up next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, boy, here we go. Claims of extortion, blackmail coming from the world's richest man, Jeff Bezos the CEO of Amazon and the owner of the Washington Post, says the publisher of the National Enquirer threatened to release explicit pictures of him that Bezos had apparently sent to his mistress. Bezos said the tabloid offered to hold off publishing the pictures if he stop investigating how the Enquirer obtain text messages that he exchanged with his lover. Bezos released an email that he says backs up his blackmail claim. One part reads, and here I'm quoting, in the interest of expediting this situation, and with the Washington Post poised to publish unsubstantiated rumors of the National Enquirer's initial report, I wanted to describe to you the photos obtain during our newsgathering, end quote. The email then goes on to describe the salacious photos and ends with this, this line, it would give us -- it would give no editor pleasure to send this email. I hope common sense can prevail and quickly, end quote. The National Enquirer's parent company said it acted lawfully and will investigate the claims. Bezos' investigators have not confirmed how the Enquirer got the text, but are floating this theory.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: They have begun to believe the Bezos camp that this publication by the National Enquirer might have been politically motivated. Gavin de Becker told us that he does not believe that Jeff Bezos' phone was hacked. He thinks it's possible that a government entity might have gotten a hold of his text messages.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Greg, you look like you're enjoying the story.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, yeah. I'm up -- I support anyone who stands up to blackmail and it's why -- you dumb leftist should stop going after billionaires because one of the only ways you can fight extortion is if you're super rich and you've got nothing to lose. Three examples, Peter Thiel --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- right? Billionaire, brought down Gawker which was an engine of malice. Donald Trump got the Daily Telegraph to apologize after smearing his wife. And now you have Bezos who is the world's richest man who actually -- I would look at this as somebody who is doing something for other people, meaning, like, there're a lot of people that can't endure extortion. We don't know. I don't know what's going on right now, but I know that I couldn't last it. The moment they find me with that giraffe -- FNC, cut me loose.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Really interesting, you in a giraffe.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: See, the mind wonders.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It was call -- and I needed the money.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: He's trying to establish a Saudi link. And he's trying to say that David Pecker invited to the White House. He brought a Saudi --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: David Pecker is the boss, the owner of the National Enquirer.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: And that will make for a very interesting headline in today's New York Post, by the way.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't get it. Could you explain that to me?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: I wish I could. It slipped my mind for a second.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Animals are great.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: But he's trying to establish a -- some type of Saudi link and, maybe, tangentially to the president. So the president would be behind his affair with Lorenz Sanchez. It originally started with the Daily Beast saying that they were focusing with his personal investigation of Michael Sanchez, the brother of Laura that started this whole thing out. So he wants to create a different situation. He also goes on to say that as soon as I brought up Saudi Arabia, they were frenetic over at the Enquirer. They wanted to stop this right away. So I hit a nerve and that's why it came forward.  So he wants to say this is an international story when it's really his personal decision to have an affair and the pictures were out there. What the Enquirer did, no one can ever back that up, but evidently it's happened over and over again. Capture and kill and pay mates.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, Dana, you know, you handled public affairs on --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Never had to handle a sex scandal.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's a hole in my resume.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, no, no, we don't want you to do that. But we want to ask how would you have thought about this because what you get is Gavin de Beckel who is the security officer for Jeff Bezos --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- making the suggestion that we just heard referred to --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And so, what would you do? Do you think that this, in fact, is -- as Greg said, a man standing up against a blackmail?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So something interesting about billionaires and social media, the ability then to not need a middleman, like a press person, right? So, he just put it out on media. Like, he didn't need to --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Put it out there.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He didn't even ask -- he didn't tell his lawyers that he was going to do it. And so, I think that -- it's very -- powerful way, yes. And also it's a way to say, like -- it's also in some ways respectful to other people. Like, I don't want to deal with the salacious details. Don't bring them to me. This is your decision to have an affair. The consequences are all yours. But I also think it's interesting because now he has said -- he said there are more pictures. So if they come out, right, I've already told you. Yep, there are more pictures and their embarrassing. Yep, that's the case. But now as the National Enquirer was to actually publish them, they'll be on -- further question of, were you trying to extort him?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I think the National Enquirer --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Which means that they might not ever be released.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: National Enquirer is on the hook for a whole lot more, Lisa, because they're in an agreement with prosecutors in terms of with the alleged payoff for porn stars from Michael Cohen or President Trump.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: This is one ugly block.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And then, they agree that they should not be involved in any kind of criminal activity. Well, this is found to be criminal, blackmail, then they can be on the hook for that previous behavior.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Right. I'm not a big fan of Jeff Bezos, but this is a pretty shrewd move that he's doing because now not only he's potentially going to get legal retribution against the National Enquirer who published this original story, but, you know, possible legal trouble and public relations trouble.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Also people cheering him on. And they were calling him an evil, you know what.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: And to that point, exactly. So now, from a public relations standpoint he's now diverted the attention away from his horrendous story about cheating on his wife and all this other stuff to now the National Enquirer, this big bully, look at them. And not only that, but they're also trying to take it even further and latest on the feet of the president. You've got Gavin, the backer, which is the guy who is running this investigation into it, has alluded now, somehow, that this is the fault of the Trump administration. That the government --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, they've said that government agency, that doesn't mean U.S. agency.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: But you can imply.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But I think they've said national security.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But it's also -- even more than that because they've also said that Michael Sanchez was responsible. And the Washington Post reported that he was a, you know, Hollywood agent connected to Trump. So, they now then try to turn this on Trump who the media hates is going to take the bait and run with it. I think it's smart --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Amazon, it was always about the packages.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm trying to get out of this segment, guys.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right. Could air travel soon be obsolete? What's some Democrats are proposing that has my colleagues just shaking their heads, has their eyes popping. That's next on THE FIVE.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: All right, this is a Fox News alert, we have just reached out to lieutenant governor's office and the press secretary had shared a statement from Fairfax after his second accuser has come forward accusing him of sexual assault. Here's the quote, "I deny this latest unsubstantiated allegation. It is demonstrably false. I have never force myself on anyone ever. I demand a full investigation into these unsubstantiated and false allegations. Such an investigation will confirm my account because I am telling the truth."  He goes on, "I will clear my good name and I have nothing to hide. I have passed two full field background checks with the FBI, and run for office in two highly contested elections with nothing like this being raised before. It is obvious that a vicious and coordinated smear campaign is being orchestrated against me. I will not resign." This is the second time he alluded to forces behind him when it looked as though he was going to elevate himself to the governorship and Northam was going to resign. Dana, how effective was that statement?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I feel like -- I feel like the word that really stuck out for me is he said demonstrably false. So that would indicate that you can demonstrate with some sort of evidence that this is false. And he will have to do that. Look, I'm for due process and for a chance for him to be able to clear his name and that what he says he would try to do. But, I don't know if he could do that before. It's like the algebra problems I had trouble with, if the train is going at this distance at this amount of miles per hour--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And then this is going this way--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Very good.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: --and they are going to meet for lunch.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right, yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You know what I mean? And then you are like, oh wait I can't get to - I can't get there.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I like how you combine that with lunch. So it's like math and food.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, so his support is falling out from under him while he's trying to demonstrably show that it's not true.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: 2000, you imagine a room, it was just - he said - she said 2018 or 2019, so 19 years later. He denies it just like last time. He denies it, they had this relation in the last accuser, the one we were dealing with before and this accuser again; it's the same type situation.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I don't know what to say to you. I mean, I'm not sure how you--

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: So he thinks is the campaign really against him?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: I don't know. I mean he'd originally - didn't he originally blame Northam, he alluded that--

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: --Northam was behind it, so I mean he's sort of passed the baton around to different people.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Actually they blame the Mayor of Richmond.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Yes, so he had blamed different people throughout this. I don't know, I actually think of all three who are sort of facing their own crisis right now, he's probably the most liable and probably the most inclined to maybe step down. And part of that too is how many more stories are there, and where is the Democrat Party going to be on this in Virginia. Are you're going to have an increased flood of people asking for him to step down?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: So I personally think that he's facing the most pressure politically to step down more so than Northam or Herring.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Hey Greg, I think you had the best point so far.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Oh thanks, thanks a lot.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: --when you said they should—

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: --they should shut down the Virginia government for two weeks to decide who is left standing. But in particular, he says he passed two FBI background checks. I don't know if they go back to college, the same thing with Kavanaugh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh yes.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: We were to--

utterances.speaker: PERINO

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino along with Lisa Boothe, Juan Williams, Brian Kilmeade, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is “The Five.” Major breaking news out of scandal plague Virginia, a defiant Ralph Northam just telling top aides he will not resign as governor despite mounting pressure to do so. This comes less than 24 hours after all of the state's Democratic congressman demanded he step aside. And just moments ago, a second woman has come forward accusing Lieutenant Governor Justin Fairfax of sexual assault. Let's go to Trace Gallagher with the latest developments, putting it all of this together for us. Trace?

utterances.speaker: TRACE GALLAGHER, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: Hi, Dana. Breaking right now, the second accuser is a woman name Meredith Watson who said this happened back in 2000 while they were both undergraduates at Duke University, and she claims at the time she share the account with several classmates who had apparently provided statements to authorities willing to back up that claim. Now, her lawyer also says she shared the story with friends in a string of e-mails on Facebook. And if that's the case, they would clearly be a fairly significant social media footprint on this story. The woman calls this -- excuse me -- a premeditated aggressive assault. She's not offering details, but she says the details of her attack are similar to the one described by Vanessa Tyson. Remember that's the first accuser. And that case, Tyson say they were at a DNC convention back in Boston in 2004, and that Fairfax asked Tyson to go to his hotel room to get documents and then began kissing. They say the kissing was consensual, and then, she alleges that he put his hand behind her neck and forcefully pulled her head towards his crotch forcing her to perform oral sex on him. He says, in turn, that relationship, that whole thing was consensual. The new accuser is now calling for him to resign as lieutenant governor and she now claims that she was upset to learn that he did this again to a second woman, being in 2004, four years after her allegations. Her attorney -- and I want to read you the statement -- just release and saying, and I'm quoting here, "at this time, Ms. Watson is reluctantly coming forward out of a strong sense of civic duty, and her belief that those seeking or serving in public office should be of the highest character. She has no interest in becoming a media personality or reliving the trauma that has greatly affected her life. Similarly, she is not seeking any financial damages." And you mentioned at the top, this is all, kind of, important because Governor Ralph Northam still maintains that he will not step down over whether or not he was involved in a racist picture in his medical school yearbook back in 1984. Fairfax will be second in line. She wants him to step down as lieutenant governor. We're still waiting to hear from the Fairfax camp about this allegation. Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, Trace, thank you so much. And so that's an important point that Trace just made. This news literally breaking while we were in the green room before we came out here. So, we haven't heard from the lieutenant governor yet. Juan, let me ask you about this that it was a week ago that we were here where we -- it was almost like to be sure that Governor Northam was going to resign. He has lost the support of all the Democrats within his own party. They're in Virginia, even in national level, the presidential candidate level. And we all believe that Justin Fairfax, lieutenant governor, could then step into his shoes. And now that looks possibly to be in doubt as well because Northam is not resigning and now you have the second accuser.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.utterance: Breaking news right here. You know, as you said as we were coming out the stuff about Justin Fairfax, the second accusation. But I think the larger story here has to do with the governor refusing, as you say, to resign at this point, which seems incredible because it's not just a few small people who are thinking, oh, we're going to stick a finger in his eye and make fun of him, and it certainly not Republicans. I'm talking about Tim Kaine and Mark Warner. I'm talking about the entire congressional delegation -- Democratic delegation for the state of Virginia saying this man has to go. In addition to which the poll numbers have plummeted, his moral authority given that awful performance when he went before the press and said, oh, you know, it seems to be that I should apologize, and, oh, no, maybe it's not me in the picture. Oh, I'm going to have an investigation. It's just so duplicitous and not believable. He has made this all about himself, Dana. And so, to that extent, if it's just him and his wife, the suggestion is that the wife has been encouraged to stay. Then, of course, he can stay for as long as he wants. He could possibly, I guess, be impeached or something like that. I don't know what the mechanism would be. But that's separate. At this moment, he has made it all about himself. It's a very selfish act damaging not only to the Democratic Party in the state but to the state.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What do you think about people that -- like Northam who go through something like this and then they refused to resign and they just hold on with no support?

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.utterance: Oh, I think a lot of this has to do with the changing nature of news. Like, you could almost -- you're confident now that you can probably --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Hold on?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- outlast anything because the news cycle is so quick. Hey, maybe something worse is going to come down. And he's actually right because worse things do come down. I mean, it's like we're watching like the worst game of war right now. You know, it's like first started with late term of abortion, then it was blackface, then sexual assault, then blackface and sexual assault. We're talking about shutting down the government. We were -- we should shutdown the Virginia government maybe for about two weeks.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But I read on Twitter -- this is what gets me, so somebody verify this, but I think it's true because it was a blue checker who said this --

utterances.speaker: BRIAN KILMEADE, HOST
utterances.utterance: OK, I will. I'm on it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK, it's true. That -- this -- Northam's staff is having him read some books to rectify his wrongdoing, and one of them is like is Roots, Alex Haley's great book. And it's just -- so, imagine that, like -- if all of us could have that luxury to rectify wrongdoings by reading books, you would have to read, of course, the Joy of Cooking.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: To call back the case of --

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But I much prefer the Joy of Hate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, well, you know that's a great book and you know it's in paperback.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, I do. I know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you for that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Indeed, indeed. Brian, what do you think?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, we had one block who is going to be about 15 minutes, we're going to talk about Virginia. That's how important to us talking about the news cycle, but now it's number one. I guess the feeling is why is Northam in a rush to start his exile? So where am I going to go? I can't go back to the medical field. It's going to be tough to line up that -- to fill up my waiting room. And I can't really go back to politics because I'm done. So he knows -- I finish up the term, there's no grounds to the other way. Virginia law reads to impeach him so I can wait this out. He actually placed a call, I understand, to Fairfax to say, you know, hang in there, buddy. You know, it will get better. That was yesterday. So, Tim Kaine and Mark Warner get together and they go, listen, let's -- you've got to leave. And he's like, I'm not going to leave. In fact, his buddy, Richard Stewart, who is a Republican, says Northam is not going to leave. He understands he has to stand up and face this, but has to explain a few things. For example, what is the name coon man mean? Who was that who you choose to put in your picture? And as the attorney general, believe it or not, Mark Herring, being that he went right to the Virginia Black Caucus and threw himself and said I'm guilty, I apologize, this is what I was thinking. They were thinking we could get Northam to step up, and then let Herring step up because we'll forgive him because it was one thing dressing like a rapper as opposed to a medical page. He was in his 20's, and Herring is just 19.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: So on degrees, Herring was supposed to be the next governor then this happens to the lieutenant governor. Northam is not going to leave. So I think things stay as they are as Northam tries to navigate his legal situation.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And some Democrats like in the state, Lisa, they were told -- you know, just stay off TV because, as to Greg's point, like, let's just get through this and then something else will happen and we'll try to figure it out. But this seems like they're in a circular firing squad in Virginian.

utterances.speaker: LISA BOOTHE, HOST
utterances.utterance: Absolutely --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And you're a Virginian.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: I am a Virginian. But --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Do you have any skeletons?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: I don't.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Get them out now.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: I don't think so -- I'm just kidding. No, none of this. Nothing like this. No, no. But to Brian's point, the reason why Northam is not going to step down is he has nowhere to go. In Virginia you serve one term so he's not going to go to run for reelection. Democrat senators, Tim Kaine and Warner aren't going anywhere, so he has nowhere else to run, politically, when he's done serving his term. And then you have the two guys under you that are facing, you know, their own public relations disaster and own scandal.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: So, why would he step down considering those things? And the reason -- everyone keeps talking about this in the context of 2020 election, but you also have statewide legislative races that are up this November and those are important. And the reason why -- I'll tell you is you look -- even that bill that Virginia Democrat -- delegate trend (ph) introduced regarding third term abortion. Right now, that was stopped because Republicans have a very slight majority in the Virginia House of Delegates. If those dynamics change, that bill may get pass. That's the same thing that happened in the state of New York when the Republicans lost the majority in the Virginia state -- sorry, New York Senate, and then Democrats are able to move forward with that third trimester abortion bill. So this is important stuff. Elections have consequences. And perhaps this ends up to bite Democrats this November.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Mention some breaking news in my ear, you know, that's where it comes in the breaking news in your ear. Governor Terry McAuliffe, former governor, has just now called for the immediate resignation of Lieutenant Governor Fairfax.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So I don't know exactly what Terry -- former Governor McAuliffe has in mind or why he felt this way, except that we now know that there's a second woman. I would say that from the Fairfax --

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: With the similar story, we should add.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. I don't know the details of that story. But I would say that those initial person, the professor from out west, never filed criminal charges and she has no intent to file criminal charges. And I think we're hearing the same thing from the woman who is making the allegations about his behavior at Duke University. The question then becomes -- so there's no criminal record, and you have, of course, varying accounts or memories. And again, we get into this this thing where, you know, forget Republican, Democrat, all that, it's just like, what -- how do you negotiate, navigate these very tricky waters? You don't want to be unfair to Fairfax in the way that we have wanted to be unfair on the Republican side to Kavanaugh.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: But do you think there's a difference in a sense where Justin Fairfax has, at least, said that they were at the same place at the same time and something went down between the two of them? Now, he says, obviously, it's consensual. Vanessa Tyson said that it was not. But it's very different than the Kavanaugh situations where -- the sense that he is admitting that something happen with this woman. They were at the same convention in 2004, and so there's at least something that happened. One is saying consensual, the other is not. Whereas with Kavanaugh, he said this never happened. I don't even remember what this woman is talking about.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But to Juan's point, which is very important, we've talked about this for a year, probably. Without due process there is no process. So you have -- it doesn't matter what side anybody is on, we're all on the same side of justice. And we have to, like -- this could really be true, it could -- might not be, we don't know.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: This happens in sports, sadly, all the time. They -- you know, you have a game on Sunday, and then accusation comes out on Thursday, and they say, hey guys, you've got to act because this just happened. How could you let them play? Well, let the process play out when there's no video and there's an accuser in a situation like this. Well, how can you let it play? Well, you don't know if he is guilty right now. How could you close circumstantial it seems obvious he is guilty. No, we have to wait. That's what the problem with sports all the time.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And that's the thing that happened with former Governor McAuliffe. So, the other thing he said is because of the second accuser, without the investigation, due process, and all that, immediate resignation, serious accusations, and that he can no longer effectively serve the people of Virginia.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think it's the power here of what you're hearing from former Governor McAuliffe is the pattern. If there's a pattern established, well, that could tip the scales.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: But then, again, I can read this, not like this guy and say I have something that would show a pattern.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Although, she's also saying -- as Trace -- Atkins --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You've got country music on your mind.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Different guy. Different guy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Trace Gallagher said --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Would that be great, though?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- lawyer say that she has emails or sort of Facebook messages. Again, this is just breaking just now, so we don't have all the details but we'll continue to follow it for you. So next, extortion, blackmail, and salacious photos, billionaire Jeff Bezos has battle with the National Enquirer, up next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, boy, here we go. Claims of extortion, blackmail coming from the world's richest man, Jeff Bezos the CEO of Amazon and the owner of the Washington Post, says the publisher of the National Enquirer threatened to release explicit pictures of him that Bezos had apparently sent to his mistress. Bezos said the tabloid offered to hold off publishing the pictures if he stop investigating how the Enquirer obtain text messages that he exchanged with his lover. Bezos released an email that he says backs up his blackmail claim. One part reads, and here I'm quoting, in the interest of expediting this situation, and with the Washington Post poised to publish unsubstantiated rumors of the National Enquirer's initial report, I wanted to describe to you the photos obtain during our newsgathering, end quote. The email then goes on to describe the salacious photos and ends with this, this line, it would give us -- it would give no editor pleasure to send this email. I hope common sense can prevail and quickly, end quote. The National Enquirer's parent company said it acted lawfully and will investigate the claims. Bezos' investigators have not confirmed how the Enquirer got the text, but are floating this theory.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: They have begun to believe the Bezos camp that this publication by the National Enquirer might have been politically motivated. Gavin de Becker told us that he does not believe that Jeff Bezos' phone was hacked. He thinks it's possible that a government entity might have gotten a hold of his text messages.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Greg, you look like you're enjoying the story.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, yeah. I'm up -- I support anyone who stands up to blackmail and it's why -- you dumb leftist should stop going after billionaires because one of the only ways you can fight extortion is if you're super rich and you've got nothing to lose. Three examples, Peter Thiel --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- right? Billionaire, brought down Gawker which was an engine of malice. Donald Trump got the Daily Telegraph to apologize after smearing his wife. And now you have Bezos who is the world's richest man who actually -- I would look at this as somebody who is doing something for other people, meaning, like, there're a lot of people that can't endure extortion. We don't know. I don't know what's going on right now, but I know that I couldn't last it. The moment they find me with that giraffe -- FNC, cut me loose.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Really interesting, you in a giraffe.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: See, the mind wonders.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It was call -- and I needed the money.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: He's trying to establish a Saudi link. And he's trying to say that David Pecker invited to the White House. He brought a Saudi --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: David Pecker is the boss, the owner of the National Enquirer.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: And that will make for a very interesting headline in today's New York Post, by the way.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't get it. Could you explain that to me?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: I wish I could. It slipped my mind for a second.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Animals are great.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: But he's trying to establish a -- some type of Saudi link and, maybe, tangentially to the president. So the president would be behind his affair with Lorenz Sanchez. It originally started with the Daily Beast saying that they were focusing with his personal investigation of Michael Sanchez, the brother of Laura that started this whole thing out. So he wants to create a different situation. He also goes on to say that as soon as I brought up Saudi Arabia, they were frenetic over at the Enquirer. They wanted to stop this right away. So I hit a nerve and that's why it came forward. So he wants to say this is an international story when it's really his personal decision to have an affair and the pictures were out there. What the Enquirer did, no one can ever back that up, but evidently it's happened over and over again. Capture and kill and pay mates.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, Dana, you know, you handled public affairs on --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Never had to handle a sex scandal.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's a hole in my resume.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, no, we don't want you to do that. But we want to ask how would you have thought about this because what you get is Gavin de Beckel who is the security officer for Jeff Bezos --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- making the suggestion that we just heard referred to --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And so, what would you do? Do you think that this, in fact, is -- as Greg said, a man standing up against a blackmail?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So something interesting about billionaires and social media, the ability then to not need a middleman, like a press person, right? So, he just put it out on media. Like, he didn't need to --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Put it out there.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He didn't even ask -- he didn't tell his lawyers that he was going to do it. And so, I think that -- it's very -- powerful way, yes. And also it's a way to say, like -- it's also in some ways respectful to other people. Like, I don't want to deal with the salacious details. Don't bring them to me. This is your decision to have an affair. The consequences are all yours. But I also think it's interesting because now he has said -- he said there are more pictures. So if they come out, right, I've already told you. Yep, there are more pictures and their embarrassing. Yep, that's the case. But now as the National Enquirer was to actually publish them, they'll be on -- further question of, were you trying to extort him?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think the National Enquirer --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Which means that they might not ever be released.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: National Enquirer is on the hook for a whole lot more, Lisa, because they're in an agreement with prosecutors in terms of with the alleged payoff for porn stars from Michael Cohen or President Trump.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: This is one ugly block.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And then, they agree that they should not be involved in any kind of criminal activity. Well, this is found to be criminal, blackmail, then they can be on the hook for that previous behavior.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Right. I'm not a big fan of Jeff Bezos, but this is a pretty shrewd move that he's doing because now not only he's potentially going to get legal retribution against the National Enquirer who published this original story, but, you know, possible legal trouble and public relations trouble.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Also people cheering him on. And they were calling him an evil, you know what.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: And to that point, exactly. So now, from a public relations standpoint he's now diverted the attention away from his horrendous story about cheating on his wife and all this other stuff to now the National Enquirer, this big bully, look at them. And not only that, but they're also trying to take it even further and latest on the feet of the president. You've got Gavin, the backer, which is the guy who is running this investigation into it, has alluded now, somehow, that this is the fault of the Trump administration. That the government --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, they've said that government agency, that doesn't mean U.S. agency.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: But you can imply.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I think they've said national security.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But it's also -- even more than that because they've also said that Michael Sanchez was responsible. And the Washington Post reported that he was a, you know, Hollywood agent connected to Trump. So, they now then try to turn this on Trump who the media hates is going to take the bait and run with it. I think it's smart --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Amazon, it was always about the packages.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm trying to get out of this segment, guys.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. Could air travel soon be obsolete? What's some Democrats are proposing that has my colleagues just shaking their heads, has their eyes popping. That's next on THE FIVE.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: All right, this is a Fox News alert, we have just reached out to lieutenant governor's office and the press secretary had shared a statement from Fairfax after his second accuser has come forward accusing him of sexual assault. Here's the quote, "I deny this latest unsubstantiated allegation. It is demonstrably false. I have never force myself on anyone ever. I demand a full investigation into these unsubstantiated and false allegations. Such an investigation will confirm my account because I am telling the truth." He goes on, "I will clear my good name and I have nothing to hide. I have passed two full field background checks with the FBI, and run for office in two highly contested elections with nothing like this being raised before. It is obvious that a vicious and coordinated smear campaign is being orchestrated against me. I will not resign." This is the second time he alluded to forces behind him when it looked as though he was going to elevate himself to the governorship and Northam was going to resign. Dana, how effective was that statement?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I feel like -- I feel like the word that really stuck out for me is he said demonstrably false. So that would indicate that you can demonstrate with some sort of evidence that this is false. And he will have to do that. Look, I'm for due process and for a chance for him to be able to clear his name and that what he says he would try to do. But, I don't know if he could do that before. It's like the algebra problems I had trouble with, if the train is going at this distance at this amount of miles per hour--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And then this is going this way--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Very good.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: --and they are going to meet for lunch.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right, yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You know what I mean? And then you are like, oh wait I can't get to - I can't get there.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I like how you combine that with lunch. So it's like math and food.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, so his support is falling out from under him while he's trying to demonstrably show that it's not true.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: 2000, you imagine a room, it was just - he said - she said 2018 or 2019, so 19 years later. He denies it just like last time. He denies it, they had this relation in the last accuser, the one we were dealing with before and this accuser again; it's the same type situation.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I don't know what to say to you. I mean, I'm not sure how you--

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: So he thinks is the campaign really against him?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: I don't know. I mean he'd originally - didn't he originally blame Northam, he alluded that--

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: --Northam was behind it, so I mean he's sort of passed the baton around to different people.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Actually they blame the Mayor of Richmond.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Yes, so he had blamed different people throughout this. I don't know, I actually think of all three who are sort of facing their own crisis right now, he's probably the most liable and probably the most inclined to maybe step down. And part of that too is how many more stories are there, and where is the Democrat Party going to be on this in Virginia. Are you're going to have an increased flood of people asking for him to step down?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: So I personally think that he's facing the most pressure politically to step down more so than Northam or Herring.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Hey Greg, I think you had the best point so far.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Oh thanks, thanks a lot.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: --when you said they should—

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: --they should shut down the Virginia government for two weeks to decide who is left standing. But in particular, he says he passed two FBI background checks. I don't know if they go back to college, the same thing with Kavanaugh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh yes.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: We were to--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Sure they do.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Of course they do.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: So what do they do, say is anyone - just do they call everyone and--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, but they go and they - I mean they look at your records, your transcripts, they talk to the school officials, but this--

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: But this is not something who ever come up, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, it should have come up. What he said.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm going to go back to what I said in the A Block that I think due process is the most important two words in the English language right now, so I think we got to wait and see. I do find it kind of interesting we spent two years chasing scandals. You know, Trump's insane, he's a Russian agent, he's racist, and yet here's this stuff coming out of the Democratic Party.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Right. This is about Democrats, a lot of people tell this story and--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: See how I did it, I turned it into a media and a political thing at once because I had nothing else to say.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I thought it was genius.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Did you think so? I'm running out of stuff to say and I want to save time for other people.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: You look for other higher-ups outside Tim Kaine and Senator Warner to come up and say, hey I believe her and I believe her, because they believed the Kavanaugh accuser.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: What - okay--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a second, it's McAuliffe who said that.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: --maybe but, what if you had somebody like McAuliffe - the former governor's call to resign, but what if one of those men said, I believe him?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They were not supposed to say that.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Right, that's what I'm saying.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: But you know what the big trend is - sorry about that Dana, it was a little late - you know what the big trend is?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know, I haven't been keeping up with it.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE

utterances.utterance: And there's a lot of people now that are blowing back on the Green New Deal. They're like, oh it's impractical, oh it's too expensive, oh it's all of this. utterances.speaker: BOOTHE

utterances.utterance: Free money, economic security, provide for those unable or unwilling to work, banned meat, healthy food for everyone, provide job training and education for all.
